p.s: Above all I think that the imagery used by Shakespeare is very important and good for explaining the topic of naturesnature's destruction by human.
And I do think that Shakespeare's persuasive power is also shown in the sonnet.
The Elizabethan time was a quite reserved time.
Everyone had his place in society.
In that perspect critique was not that common and critizingcriticizing the whole of humanity neither.
And given those aspects ShakespearShakespeare could be seen as quote revolutionary.
The protection of nature was not a big deal at all and ShakespearShakespeare trying to change that by using his enormous influence is quite impressive.
But it's not that this is the only sonnet kind of criticizing the Elizabethan society.
Killing a king or showing an image of love which failed due to actual boundriesboundaries in that time, he is revolutionary when it comes to his writings.
So I think that this Sonnet 65 fits very well with his others.
And I think that you can, in the endEnd, see that he really adores poetry and writing.
He implies that his writings have the power to safesave and embody the beauty of nature, which is declining day by day.
So I think that, allthoughalthough many people did not share his thoughts of his time, his sonnet is very persuasive.
In the way he writes, compares and personificates and takes untypicalatypical seems to write, he delivers a persuasive image of how he thinks about the topic.
